awd_titl_txt: RIPS Type 2: Collaborative Research: Towards resilient computational models of electricity-gas ICI
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the fastest growing consumers of Natural Gas (NG) is the electricity sector, through the use of NG-fired power plants. Already a large portion of the electricity portfolio mix in many regions in the US, NG-fired power generation is increasing even further with growing penetration of renewable energy due to the former's fast, on-demand response capabilities, and latter's characteristics of intermittency and uncertainty. As a result, NG and electricity networks are getting increasingly linked and interdependent. Tighter coordination and information sharing between electric grid operators and NG suppliers is therefore becoming highly necessary to have a resilient interdependent critical infrastructure of electricity and NG. 

This proposal seeks to create computational models of this infrastructure, gain analytical insight into the existing infrastructure in response to system and policy changes, and design guidelines for a coordinated infrastructure with improved resilience. These models are based, wherever possible, on real data from industrial partners and incorporate scaled versions of the electrical and NG networks of the New England area.  Specific tools to reach these objectives include security constrained unit commitment, a powerful tool that provides optimal dispatch of power generation for a given network topology and policies, dynamic market mechanisms and hybrid network science,  that permit analysis of uncertainty on the infrastructure, and cyber-security based resiliency tools for malicious and non-malicious events.
org_div_long_name: Office of Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI)

por.por_cntn:
World over, there’s a need to move towards clean energy. In power grids, the implication is that a growing percentage of generation will come from renewables such as solar and wind sources. This in turn brings in high uncertainty and intermittency, necessitating a reliable, fast, and relatively clean source of generation such as Natural Gas (NG) as a stand-by generation resource. All of this necessitates a detailed study of the interdependence between NG and the electricity infrastructures. This is the focus of this project. In addition to creating models of the two infrastructures and their independence, our study focused on key aspects where higher coordination is needed. Our analysis reveals that coordination and information sharing will need to occur at multiple time-scales, from markets and economic dispatch to control for frequency regulation.

New dynamic market mechanisms were developed that help coordinate the gas-electricity operation. These mechanisms must enable and exploit the flexibility of both systems to enhance the resilience of the integrated gas-electricity system. These dynamic models of the interconnected infrastructures provide the pathway for the design of  resilient and robust control and coordination feedback loops.  Specifically, a new Dynamic Regulation Market Mechanism (DRMM) has been developed to ensure frequency regulation with optimal service allocation while enabling DR units to participate in the market for the provision of this service. Further, to analyze the impact of increased intermittent renewable penetration on natural gas generation, multi-variant regression analysis  has been deployed to forecast three scenarios of increased wind/solar penetration in the electric grid and analyze their potential impacts on gas price and electricity price. We developed settlement rules for the new DRMM and show that the DRMM will minimize the energy portion of the settlement at steady state, compared to typical AGC which will not. 

A resilience metric is proposed, that quantifies how the coordinated infrastructure recovers from a severe anomaly. The DRMM along with frequency regulation models for optimal service allocation with DR units that can participate in real time in the market was implied. We then subjected the combined models to communication attacks,  such as Denial of Service attacks and integrity attacks that can change the set points at the generators. We studied the impact of the attack at scale and devised resiliency strategies for them.

A misalignment of incentives in the gas pipeline construction process has caused growth of gas-fired generation to outpace investment in new pipelines in New England. Limited gas capacity to the region has resulted in power reliability issues, particularly during severe winter weather when gas demand is high. The majority of proposed solutions have focused on increasing gas supply. However, demand response in the natural gas retail market is a potential alternative answer. To quantify the benefits of gas demand response regional and state level price elasticities of demand for natural gas must be known. We estimated the price elasticity of demand for the national, regional and state levels for the residential, commercial and industrial sectors. Differences in demand estimates were observed when performed at the different aggregate data levels and sectors. However, not all the regional and state estimates obtained for each sector showed statistically significant differences from each other or the national level. The short-run regional estimates for New England were used in a simple demonstration of gas demand response to show how they could have been used to mitigate the effects of the 2014 cold snap on electricity generation. Prices were optimized such that they reduced gas demand from retail markets by the amount of fuel that generators were short while minimizing the total deadweight loss. In summary, this thrust attempts to provide updated regional estimates of the price elasticity of demand for natural gas that can then be used later to quantify the economic implications of gas demand response in New England.

Lastly, a fully distributed market-based transactive control algorithm has been developed for attaining solution to the ACOPF problem in distribution grids.

 Several post-doctoral students, PhD students, MS students, and undergraduate students were trained in all aspects of this project. A course at MIT included highlights of this project in one of the classes. Frequent telecons and discussions between all members of the project have generated fundamental insight into the interface between economics and engineering, engineering and computer science, and systems design and infrastructure design. Most noteworthy is that the problem statement and overall scope of the project have now grabbed the attention of key stakeholders in this process. A case in point is the recent security study reported by ISO-New England, that underlined the importance of studying the relation between natural gas and the electricity sector. We expect the results of this project will serve as a first step towards developing building blocks that can mitigate the impact of cyberattacks on power grids.
